content:
Diagnosis:
Metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma with bone and brain metastases
Initial PSA 567 (January 2024)
CHEK2 mutation positive

Previous Treatment:
Androgen deprivation therapy commenced January 2024
Docetaxel chemotherapy commenced February 2024 - completed 3 cycles
Emergency whole brain radiotherapy March 2024 for symptomatic cerebral metastases

Previous medical history:
Type 2 diabetes
Hypertension
Chronic kidney disease stage 3

Current medications:
Leuprorelin 3-monthly
Dexamethasone 4mg twice daily
Abiraterone 1000mg daily
Prednisolone 5mg twice daily
Apixaban for cancer-associated thrombosis

Current situation:
Progressive disease with rising PSA (now 890) and new neurological symptoms

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with his wife. Unfortunately, he has experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past two weeks with worsening mobility and new onset confusion. His performance status has declined from 1 to 3. Despite initial response to whole brain radiotherapy, he has developed recurrent headaches and right-sided weakness. Recent MRI shows progression of cerebral metastases with associated edema.

His PSA has risen from 567 to 890 despite being on abiraterone for the past 6 weeks. He has also developed new bone pain affecting his thoracic spine and right hip, requiring increased opiate analgesia.

After careful discussion with [redacted name] and his wife, we have agreed to discontinue abiraterone given the clear evidence of disease progression. Given his declining performance status and the aggressive nature of his disease, I have recommended transition to best supportive care with involvement of the palliative care team. I have increased his dexamethasone dose to help manage the cerebral edema and referred him urgently to the palliative care team.

The plan is for telephone review by the palliative care team within 48 hours. I have also arranged urgent hospice assessment. We will continue current medications including dexamethasone and analgesia, but discontinue abiraterone and prednisolone. I have provided emergency contact details and arranged weekly community nurse follow-up.
